repnme.cdata!:
Peru - Indigenous and Afro-Peruvian Peoples
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Indigenous and Afro-Peruvian Peoples
            Development Project for Peru had the following ratings: the
            outcome was unsatisfactory, the sustainability was unlikely,
            the institutional development impact was negligible, the
            Bank performance was satisfactory, and borrower performance
            was unsatisfactory. The lessons learned indicate that the
            pre-design and design, in this type of project, must collect
            adequate and validated information. Projects aimed at
            indigenous groups and Afro-descendants must have a simple
            design. The activities of the projects aimed at indigenous
            groups and Afro-descendants must include effective, agile
            responses for community investment. The value of the project
            has implications which must be foreseen when selecting the
            type of Bank instruments to be used in this kind of project.
            This type of projects need to count with institutional
            counterpart, legitimated by the beneficiaries. Institutional
            arrangements require well-defined roles and functions.
            Indigenous and Afro-descendant development could generate
            important benefits in the decentralization scheme.
            Empowering excluded groups requires a lengthy process of
            give and take where power gains have to be negotiated every
            step of the way.

repnme.cdata!:
Peru - Indigenous and Afro-Peruvian Peoples
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Indigenous and Afro-Peruvian Peoples
            Development Project supports the strategic objective of
            reducing an extreme poverty, by building the capacity of
            communities, and organizations to foster their own
            development. The components includes: 1) institutional
            strengthening of the Technical Secretariat of Indigenous
            Affairs, and the Multisectoral Commission of Indigenous
            Affairs. Equipment and office supplies, in addition to
            technical staff, operating costs, and training will be
            financed, as will the Geographic Information System
            software, and exchanges with institutions, working on
            capacity building; 2) Training will be provided for
            participatory planning of community sub-projects, and
            related financial management, and administration.
            Entrepreneurial, and income generating activities will be
            strengthened, while the cultural patrimony, and development
            of human resources will be reinforced through
            organizational, technical, and legal training; 3) technical
            assistance will be provided to revise the legal framework
            regarding indigenous peoples, and, consultation for legal
            reform development will be financed; 4) training on
            community rights, issues, and cultures will be provided for
            the development of an awareness campaign and information; 5)
            pre-investment studies will focus on financial resource
            allocation, and participatory community development; and, 6)
            project management costs will be provided.
